The money talks, and I've got the charm to make it sing. I recall this one time, I was dealing with a potential buyer from a high-end restaurant in Asia. He was hesitant at first, didn't want to get involved with "unsustainable" practices, as he put it. But I took him out for a drink, showed him the numbers – the demand for shark fin soup, the prices it fetches, the profit margins. I told him, "Listen, this is a business, not a hobby. You want to make money, or do you want to save the world? Because if it's the latter, you're in the wrong game."

I explained to him how the fins are just a byproduct, that the sharks are already being caught anyway, and that we're just maximizing the value of the catch. I told him about the other buyers I've worked with, the ones who don't ask questions, who just want the product and are willing to pay top dollar. I showed him the pictures of my boats, my crew, my operation – all legitimate, all above board, or so it seems.

He was still hesitant, but I could see the greed in his eyes. So, I made him an offer he couldn't refuse. I gave him a "special deal" on the first shipment, a discount that would make his head spin. And I told him, "Look, I'm not asking you to make a moral judgment. I'm asking you to make a business decision. You want to be a player in this industry, or do you want to be a footnote?"

He took the deal, and now he's one of my best customers. And let me tell you, he's not the only one. I've got a whole network of buyers and partners who see things my way. They know that in this business, you've got to be willing to get your hands dirty. And I'm the one who's willing to do whatever it takes to get the job done.

We all know what's at stake, and we all know what we're willing to do to get it.
